citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There was 1 guinea pig observed with a health condition requiring treatment in accordance with the Program of Veterinary
Care or consultation with the attending veterinarian. A tri-color adult guinea pig in Pen 111 had an abnormal left eye. The
eye was protruding beyond the surface of the eyelid and had dark crusts and scabs covering the surface. Underneath the
crusts and scabs appeared red and gentle prodding caused the guinea pig to vocalize which may indicate pain. The
licensee had not observed the condition, had not contacted the attending veterinarian, and was not treating the condition.
Eye abnormalities can affect the vision, can be indicative of disease or injury, can be painful, and affect the overall health
and well-being of the animal.
The facility must contact the attending veterinarian to have the guinea pig with the eye abnormality evaluated in order to
determine an appropriate plan for diagnosis and treatment.
Correct by: November 7, 2024
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by January 5, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Your license is currently expired and no regulated activity can be conducted.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2)  Direct Repeat
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There was 1 guinea pig observed with a health condition requiring treatment in accordance with the Program of Veterinary 
Care or consultation with the attending veterinarian. A tri-color adult guinea pig in Pen 111 had an abnormal left eye. The 
eye was protruding beyond the surface of the eyelid and had dark crusts and scabs covering the surface. Underneath the 
crusts and scabs appeared red and gentle prodding caused the guinea pig to vocalize which may indicate pain. The 
licensee had not observed the condition, had not contacted the attending veterinarian, and was not treating the condition. 
Eye abnormalities can affect the vision, can be indicative of disease or injury, can be painful, and affect the overall health 
and well-being of the animal.  
The facility must contact the attending veterinarian to have the guinea pig with the eye abnormality evaluated in order to 
determine an appropriate plan for diagnosis and treatment. 
Correct by: November 7, 2024 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by January 5, 2025 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee 
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Your license is currently expired and no regulated activity can be conducted.
